1→---
     2→title: 'The Importance of Investing, ETFs Are the Best Choice for Most People'
     3→publishedAt: '2024-10-05'
     4→summary: 'Cryptocurrency ETFs are inevitably a major trend for the future.'
     5→category: 'investing'
     6→---
     7→
     8→## KK ETFs INDEX
     9→
    10→DYOR! DYOR! DYOR! Last updated: **2024/1/1 ～ 2026/01/28**
    11→
    12→For most people, ETFs may be a more suitable investment approach. The United States is approving more cryptocurrency ETFs, and the next market wave will still be crypto equities, stablecoins, and Perp DEX, with the market being gradually divided.
    13→
    14→One principle: Hold BTC in bull markets, accumulate altcoins in bear markets. (Perhaps there are no more bull and bear markets, just volatility)
    15→
    16→Criteria for ETF selection: Favored by capitalists and institutions, has user base, has trading volume, team fundamentals are solid, REV value, no major bugs.
    17→
    18→A thought: After large-scale cryptocurrencies and DAPPs emerge, what are the essential needs? (Perhaps RWA and payments--20250906), RWA tokenization, stablecoin will be continue war --20251125
    19→
    20→Quality crypto assets: BTC, ETH, Hyperliquid
    21→
    22→L1: BNB, SOL, SUI, Canton(CC)
    23→
    24→Infrastructure: LINK, AAVE, SKY, UNI, SYRUP
    25→
    26→AI: SENT
    27→
    28→Coins that survived two bull-bear cycles and continue to reach new highs: XRP, DOGE => Relative strength index, institutional era
    29→
    30→Web3 US stocks: BLOCK (XYZ), COINBASE(COIN), RGTI, CRDO, BMNR, DFDV, ACHR, CRCL (Circle)
    31→
    32→US stocks: FLANNG, PLTR, Figma, DDOG, NET
    33→
    34→After HIP-3, Hype supports mainstream US stock trading and unlisted US AI giants and tech companies [hyperliquid](https://app.hyperliquid.xyz/trade)
    35→
    36→Purchase US stocks and crypto equities: [Jupiter](https://jup.ag/)
    37→
    38→Emerging US stock purchase platform: [Stablestock](https://app.stablestock.finance/trade/market)
    39→
    40→Compliant US stock purchase platform (in beta whitelist): [Ondo](https://app.ondo.finance/)

content.text:
Perfect! Now I have a comprehensive understanding of the codebase. Let me provide you with a thorough analysis:

## Comprehensive Portfolio Codebase Analysis

### 1. **Project Structure - Next.js App Router**

This is a **Next.js 16.1.1 project using the App Router** (not pages router). The project structure reveals:

```
/src/app
├── layout.tsx           (Root layout)
├── page.tsx            (Home page / /)
├── blog/
│   ├── page.tsx        (Blog listing page)
│   ├── blog-client.tsx (Client component for filtering/pagination)
│   └── [slug]/
│       └── page.tsx    (Dynamic blog post page)
└── stack/
    ├── page.tsx        (Stack page)
    └── stack-client.tsx (Client component for tabs)
```

**Key Technologies:**
- Next.js 16.1.1 with App Router
- React 19.2.3
- TypeScript
- TailwindCSS with @tailwindcss/typography
- Shadcn/ui component library
- MDX with rehype/remark pipeline

### 2. **Blog and Stack Page Architecture**

#### **Blog Pages** (`/Users/kk/indie/portfolio/src/app/blog/`)

**`page.tsx`** - Server Component:
- Fetches all blog posts using `getBlogPosts()`
- Returns metadata (title, description)
- Renders `BlogClient` component passing posts array

**`blog-client.tsx`** - Client Component:
- Interactive filtering by 6 categories: All, Thoughts, Research, Investing, Economics, Philosophy
- Pagination (10 posts per page with smart pagination UI)
- Sorts posts by date descending
- Features smooth scroll to top on pagination

**`[slug]/page.tsx`** - Dynamic Blog Post Page:
- Static generation using `generateStaticParams()` for all blog posts
- Generates metadata dynamically per post (title, keywords, OG images)
- Renders structured JSON-LD for SEO
- Includes table of contents component (generated from markdown headings)
- Displays article with prose styling and syntax highlighting
- Includes scroll-to-top button

#### **Stack Page** (`/Users/kk/indie/portfolio/src/app/stack/`)

**`page.tsx`** - Server Component:
- Simple wrapper with metadata
- Returns `StackClient` component

**`stack-client.tsx`** - Client Component:
- Tab interface with 4 sections:
  1. **Crypto Cards** - Payment cards (Bybit, Coinbase, Crypto.com, Binance) with pros/cons
  2. **Books** - Educational books with 10 categories (intro, thinking, economics, etc.)
  3. **Data Sources** - Crypto analytics tools with 8 categories
  4. **AI Tools** - AI assistants with 6 categories
- Each section has category filtering
- Responsive grid layout with hover effects

### 3. **MDX Content Loading and Rendering**

**Content Utilities** (`/Users/kk/indie/portfolio/src/data/blog.ts`):

The blog system uses a sophisticated content pipeline:

1. **File Reading**: `getMDXFiles()` - Reads all `.mdx` files from `/content` directory
2. **YAML Frontmatter Parsing**: Uses `gray-matter` library to extract metadata
3. **Markdown to HTML Pipeline**:
   - `remark-parse` - Parse markdown
   - `remark-gfm` - GitHub flavored markdown support
   - `remark-rehype` - Convert markdown to rehype AST
   - `rehype-pretty-code` - Syntax highlighting with Shiki (light/dark themes)
   - `rehype-stringify` - Convert to HTML string

4. **Table of Contents Generation**:
   - `extractToc()` - Parses heading hierarchy (h1-h6)
   - Generates IDs from heading text for anchor links
   - Returns array of `TocItem` with id, text, and level

5. **Heading ID Enhancement**:
   - `addHeadingIds()` - Adds generated IDs to HTML heading tags
   - `generateId()` - Creates slug-friendly IDs, supporting Chinese characters

**Content Post Structure**:
```typescript
type Post = {
  metadata: {
    title: string;
    publishedAt: string;      // ISO date format
    summary: string;
    image?: string;           // Optional OG image
    category?: Category;      // One of 5 categories
  };
  slug: string;
  source: string;            // HTML content
  toc?: TocItem[];          // Generated table of contents
}
```

### 4. **Content/investing.mdx File Contents**

Perfect! Now I have a comprehensive understanding of the codebase. Let me provide you with a thorough analysis:

## Comprehensive Portfolio Codebase Analysis

### 1. **Project Structure - Next.js App Router**

This is a **Next.js 16.1.1 project using the App Router** (not pages router). The project structure reveals:

```
/src/app
├── layout.tsx           (Root layout)
├── page.tsx            (Home page / /)
├── blog/
│   ├── page.tsx        (Blog listing page)
│   ├── blog-client.tsx (Client component for filtering/pagination)
│   └── [slug]/
│       └── page.tsx    (Dynamic blog post page)
└── stack/
    ├── page.tsx        (Stack page)
    └── stack-client.tsx (Client component for tabs)
```

**Key Technologies:**
- Next.js 16.1.1 with App Router
- React 19.2.3
- TypeScript
- TailwindCSS with @tailwindcss/typography
- Shadcn/ui component library
- MDX with rehype/remark pipeline

### 2. **Blog and Stack Page Architecture**

#### **Blog Pages** (`/Users/kk/indie/portfolio/src/app/blog/`)

**`page.tsx`** - Server Component:
- Fetches all blog posts using `getBlogPosts()`
- Returns metadata (title, description)
- Renders `BlogClient` component passing posts array

**`blog-client.tsx`** - Client Component:
- Interactive filtering by 6 categories: All, Thoughts, Research, Investing, Economics, Philosophy
- Pagination (10 posts per page with smart pagination UI)
- Sorts posts by date descending
- Features smooth scroll to top on pagination

**`[slug]/page.tsx`** - Dynamic Blog Post Page:
- Static generation using `generateStaticParams()` for all blog posts
- Generates metadata dynamically per post (title, keywords, OG images)
- Renders structured JSON-LD for SEO
- Includes table of contents component (generated from markdown headings)
- Displays article with prose styling and syntax highlighting
- Includes scroll-to-top button

#### **Stack Page** (`/Users/kk/indie/portfolio/src/app/stack/`)

**`page.tsx`** - Server Component:
- Simple wrapper with metadata
- Returns `StackClient` component

**`stack-client.tsx`** - Client Component:
- Tab interface with 4 sections:
  1. **Crypto Cards** - Payment cards (Bybit, Coinbase, Crypto.com, Binance) with pros/cons
  2. **Books** - Educational books with 10 categories (intro, thinking, economics, etc.)
  3. **Data Sources** - Crypto analytics tools with 8 categories
  4. **AI Tools** - AI assistants with 6 categories
- Each section has category filtering
- Responsive grid layout with hover effects

### 3. **MDX Content Loading and Rendering**

**Content Utilities** (`/Users/kk/indie/portfolio/src/data/blog.ts`):

The blog system uses a sophisticated content pipeline:

1. **File Reading**: `getMDXFiles()` - Reads all `.mdx` files from `/content` directory
2. **YAML Frontmatter Parsing**: Uses `gray-matter` library to extract metadata
3. **Markdown to HTML Pipeline**:
   - `remark-parse` - Parse markdown
   - `remark-gfm` - GitHub flavored markdown support
   - `remark-rehype` - Convert markdown to rehype AST
   - `rehype-pretty-code` - Syntax highlighting with Shiki (light/dark themes)
   - `rehype-stringify` - Convert to HTML string

4. **Table of Contents Generation**:
   - `extractToc()` - Parses heading hierarchy (h1-h6)
   - Generates IDs from heading text for anchor links
   - Returns array of `TocItem` with id, text, and level

5. **Heading ID Enhancement**:
   - `addHeadingIds()` - Adds generated IDs to HTML heading tags
   - `generateId()` - Creates slug-friendly IDs, supporting Chinese characters

**Content Post Structure**:
```typescript
type Post = {
  metadata: {
    title: string;
    publishedAt: string;      // ISO date format
    summary: string;
    image?: string;           // Optional OG image
    category?: Category;      // One of 5 categories
  };
  slug: string;
  source: string;            // HTML content
  toc?: TocItem[];          // Generated table of contents
}
```

content.content:
# Portfolio Page Layout and Structure

## Overall Organization

The portfolio page features a two-section navigation structure with "Featured" and "Investments" tabs, allowing users to toggle between curated and comprehensive investment listings.

## Display Format

Investments are presented as **interactive card tiles** arranged in a responsive grid layout. Each card contains:

- **Company logo** (image-based)
- **Company name** (text link)
- **Brief description** (single line, ~50-80 characters)
- **Clickable link** to company website

## Featured Section

This section highlights key portfolio companies with the introductory statement: "We invest in, build, and contribute to companies and protocols with as little as $1M and as much as $100M+."

Featured companies include Uniswap, Coinbase, Optimism, Phantom, and Fireblocks among others.

## Investments Section

Contains a more extensive list of portfolio companies organized similarly, spanning categories like:
- DeFi protocols
- Crypto exchanges
- Gaming platforms
- Infrastructure providers
- Stablecoin projects

## Visual Style

The design uses a clean, minimalist approach with:
- Monochromatic card layouts
- Consistent grid spacing
- Hover-interactive elements
- Professional typography
- Dark/light theme compatibility

The page emphasizes accessibility through descriptive categories paired with each investment, making portfolio diversity immediately apparent.

---
title: 'The Importance of Investing, ETFs Are the Best Choice for Most People'
publishedAt: '2024-10-05'
summary: 'Cryptocurrency ETFs are inevitably a major trend for the future.'
category: 'investing'
---

## KK ETFs INDEX

DYOR! DYOR! DYOR! Last updated: **2024/1/1 ～ 2026/01/28**

For most people, ETFs may be a more suitable investment approach. The United States is approving more cryptocurrency ETFs, and the next market wave will still be crypto equities, stablecoins, and Perp DEX, with the market being gradually divided.

One principle: Hold BTC in bull markets, accumulate altcoins in bear markets. (Perhaps there are no more bull and bear markets, just volatility)

Criteria for ETF selection: Favored by capitalists and institutions, has user base, has trading volume, team fundamentals are solid, REV value, no major bugs.

A thought: After large-scale cryptocurrencies and DAPPs emerge, what are the essential needs? (Perhaps RWA and payments--20250906), RWA tokenization, stablecoin will be continue war --20251125

Quality crypto assets: BTC, ETH, Hyperliquid

L1: BNB, SOL, SUI, Canton(CC)

Infrastructure: LINK, AAVE, SKY, UNI, SYRUP

AI: SENT

Coins that survived two bull-bear cycles and continue to reach new highs: XRP, DOGE => Relative strength index, institutional era

Web3 US stocks: BLOCK (XYZ), COINBASE(COIN), RGTI, CRDO, BMNR, DFDV, ACHR, CRCL (Circle)

US stocks: FLANNG, PLTR, Figma, DDOG, NET

After HIP-3, Hype supports mainstream US stock trading and unlisted US AI giants and tech companies [hyperliquid](https://app.hyperliquid.xyz/trade)

Purchase US stocks and crypto equities: [Jupiter](https://jup.ag/)

Emerging US stock purchase platform: [Stablestock](https://app.stablestock.finance/trade/market)

Compliant US stock purchase platform (in beta whitelist): [Ondo](https://app.ondo.finance/)

input.content:
# Plan: Create /fund Investment Portfolio Page

## Context
User wants a dedicated page at `/fund` to display their investment portfolio (currently in `content/investing.mdx`). The page should be parallel to `/blog` and `/stack`, referencing Paradigm's portfolio style (card grid layout with categories).

## Files to Create
1. **`src/data/fund.ts`** — Investment data extracted from investing.mdx, structured as typed arrays
2. **`src/app/fund/page.tsx`** — Server component (metadata + render client)
3. **`src/app/fund/fund-client.tsx`** — Client component with category tabs and card grid

## Files to Modify
4. **`src/data/resume.tsx`** — Add `/fund` to `navbar` array

## Data Structure (`src/data/fund.ts`)

```ts
type AssetCategory = 'quality' | 'l1' | 'infra' | 'ai' | 'legacy' | 'web3-stock' | 'us-stock' | 'platform';

type Asset = {
  name: string;
  ticker?: string;       // e.g. "BTC", "COIN"
  category: AssetCategory;
  description: string;
  link?: string;
};
```

Data from investing.mdx mapped into these categories:
- **Quality Crypto**: BTC, ETH, Hyperliquid
- **L1**: BNB, SOL, SUI, Canton(CC)
- **Infrastructure**: LINK, AAVE, SKY, UNI, SYRUP
- **AI**: SENT
- **Legacy**: XRP, DOGE
- **Web3 US Stocks**: BLOCK, COINBASE, RGTI, CRDO, BMNR, DFDV, ACHR, CRCL
- **US Stocks**: FLANNG, PLTR, Figma, DDOG, NET
- **Platforms**: Jupiter, Stablestock, Ondo, Hyperliquid

Also include the philosophy/principles text at the top of the page.

## Page Layout (Paradigm-inspired)

```
┌──────────────────────────────────┐
│  fund                            │  ← h1 title
│  Investment philosophy text...   │  ← intro paragraph from MDX
│  Last updated: 2026/01/28       │
│                                  │
│  [All] [Quality] [L1] [Infra]   │  ← category filter tabs
│  [AI] [Legacy] [Web3 Stocks]    │
│  [US Stocks] [Platforms]        │
│                                  │
│  ┌─────────┐ ┌─────────┐       │
│  │ BTC     │ │ ETH     │       │  ← responsive card grid
│  │ desc    │ │ desc    │       │     (2-3 cols on desktop)
│  └─────────┘ └─────────┘       │
│  ...                            │
└──────────────────────────────────┘
```

Each card: ticker/name, short description, optional external link. Clean minimal style matching the existing site.

## Implementation Steps

1. Create `src/data/fund.ts` with types and asset data
2. Create `src/app/fund/page.tsx` — simple server wrapper like stack/page.tsx
3. Create `src/app/fund/fund-client.tsx` — follows stack-client.tsx pattern: BlurFade animations, category filter buttons, responsive grid of asset cards
4. Add nav entry in `src/data/resume.tsx`: `{ href: '/fund', icon: TrendingUpIcon, label: 'Fund' }` (import `TrendingUpIcon` from lucide-react)

## Verification
- Run `npm run dev` / `next dev` and visit `/fund`
- Check category filtering works
- Check responsive layout (mobile / desktop)
- Verify navbar shows the Fund link
